introduction.content: In recent years, the rapid growth of artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) has resulted in increasingly complex and large models in pursuit of higher accuracy and range of use cases [1] . The substantial growth rate of model computation exceeds efficiency gains realized through Moore and Dennard technology scaling [2] , indicating a looming limit to continued advancements with existing techniques. This issue is compounded by the open challenges of adapting such methods for resource-constrained edge devices (tinyML) in order to enable pervasive and decentralized intelligence through the Internet of Things (IoT) [3] . As such, the urgency for exploring new resource-efficient and scalable computing architectures has intensified. Neuromorphic computing has emerged as a promising area in addressing these challenges, aiming to unlock key hallmarks of biological intelligence by porting primitives and computational strategies employed in the brain into engineered computing devices and algorithms [4] , [5] , [6] . Neuromorphic systems hold a critical position in the investigation of novel architectures, as the brain exemplifies an exceptional model for accomplishing scalable, energy-efficient, and real-time embodied computation. Initially, the term “neuromorphic” referred specifically to approaches that aimed to emulate the biophysics of the brain by leveraging physical properties of silicon, as proposed by Mead in the 1980’s [7] . However, the field of neuromorphic computing research has since grown to encompass a wide range of brain-inspired computing techniques at the algorithmic, hardware, and system levels [4] . While the range of approaches is diverse, neuromorphic computing research generally utilizes mechanisms emulating or simulating biophysical properties more closely than conventional methods, aiming to reproduce high-level performance and efficiency characteristics of biological neural systems. Neuromorphic algorithms [8] encompass neuroscience-inspired methods which strive towards goals of expanded learning capabilities, such as predictive intelligence, data efficiency, and adaptation, and include approaches such as spiking neural networks (SNNs) and primitives of neuron dynamics, plastic synapses, and heterogeneous network architectures. Algorithm exploration often makes use of simulated execution on readily-available conventional hardware such as CPUs and GPUs, with the goal of driving design requirements for next-generation neuromorphic hardware. Neuromorphic systems [9] are composed of algorithms deployed to hardware, which seek greater energy efficiency, real-time processing capabilities, and resilience compared to conventional systems. Neuromorphic hardware utilizes a variety of biologically-inspired hardware approaches, including analog neuron emulation, event-based computation, non-von-Neumann architectures, and in-memory processing. Neuromorphic systems target a wide range of applications, from neuroscientific exploration, to low-power edge intelligence and datacenter-scale acceleration. Despite its promises, progress in the field of neuromorphic research is impeded due to the absence of fair and widely-adopted objective metrics and benchmarks [8] , [10] . Without such benchmarks, the validity of neuromorphic solutions cannot be directly quantified, hindering the research community from measuring technological advancement. Standard and rigorous benchmarking is necessary for the neuromorphic community to objectively assess and compare the achievements of novel approaches, and make evidence-based decisions on which directions show promise for achieving breakthrough efficiency, speed, and intelligence, thereby helping to focus research and commercialization efforts on techniques that concretely improve on prior work and conventional computing. Neuromorphic benchmarks have been previously proposed for classical vision [11] , [12] and audition tasks [13] , open-loop [14] and closed-loop [15] tasks, and for SNN simulator performance assessment [16] . While prior works have made valuable contributions, there are opportunities to further advance the field by addressing three outstanding challenges: Lack of a formal definition – The variety of approaches to exploring brain-inspired principles creates difficulties in defining a set of criteria for what should be benchmarked as a “neuromorphic” solution. Closed definitions can impose narrow assumptions and thus risk unfairly excluding promising methods. This challenge necessitates inclusive benchmarks that can be applied generally across the spectrum of potential approaches, allowing for flexible implementation while focusing on task capabilities and metrics of interest such as temporal processing and efficiency. Furthermore, the benchmarks should ideally allow for direct comparison of neuromorphic and conventional approaches. Implementation diversity – A wide array of different frameworks targeting different goals, such as neuroscientific exploration [17] and automatic SNN training [18] , are used in neuromorphic research. This diversity, which has been instrumental in exploring the landscape of bio-inspired techniques following different methodologies and abstraction levels, comes at the cost of portability and standardization, which in turn limits the ease of benchmark implementation. Benchmarks require common infrastructure that unites tooling to enable actionable implementation and comparison of new methods. Rapid research evolution – Neuromorphic approaches are continually and rapidly evolving as part of an emerging field. As the research community continues to make technological progress, so too should benchmark suites and methodology expand to foster inclusion and capture salient performance metrics. An iterative benchmark framework with structured versioning will facilitate productive foundational and evolving performance evaluation. To tackle these challenges, this article presents NeuroBench, a dual-track, multi-task benchmark framework. NeuroBench addresses the existing neuromorphic benchmark challenges by advancing prior work in three distinct ways. Firstly, the benchmark framework reduces assumptions regarding the specific solution being assessed, encouraging inclusive participation of neuromorphic and non-neuromorphic approaches by utilizing general, task-level benchmarking and hierarchical metric definitions which capture key performance indicators of interest. Secondly, the NeuroBench benchmarks are associated with a common open-source benchmark harness tool which facilitates actionable benchmark implementation and offers structure for further expansion to neuromorphic algorithm frameworks and systems. Finally, NeuroBench establishes an iterative, community-driven initiative designed to evolve over time to ensure representation and relevance to neuromorphic research, analogous to the well-established MLPerf benchmark framework for machine learning [19] , [20] . As a whole, NeuroBench intends to align the neuromorphic research community on standard benchmarking, providing a dynamically evolving platform to ensure ongoing relevance and facilitate advancements through workshops, competitions, and a centralized leaderboard. As Fig. 1 shows, the NeuroBench framework involves two tracks to enable agile algorithm and system development. As an emerging technology, neuromorphic hardware has not converged to a single platform which is commercially available, thus a large fraction of neuromorphic research explores algorithmic advancement on conventional systems which may not be optimal for performance. Thus, NeuroBench consists of an algorithm track for hardware-independent evaluation and a system track for fully deployed solutions. The algorithm track defines four novel benchmarks for neuromorphic methods across diverse domains, namely few-shot continual learning, computer vision, motor cortical decoding, and chaotic forecasting, and utilizes complexity metrics to analyze solution costs. Such hardware-independent benchmarking enables algorithmic exploration and prototyping, especially when simulating algorithm execution on non-neuromorphic platforms. Meanwhile, the system track defines standard protocols to measure the real-world speed and efficiency of neuromorphic hardware on benchmarks ranging from standard machine learning tasks to promising fields for neuromorphic systems, such as optimization. Up-to-date information on the latest benchmarks and official results can be found on the NeuroBench website ( https://neurobench.ai/ ). Fig. 1: The two NeuroBench tracks: algorithms and systems. Grey boxes designate what is defined by the benchmark, and orange boxes indicate what is unique to each solution. Connecting arrows between the two tracks denote the co-innovation between the tracks and the cross-stack innovation enabled by this approach. Between algorithm and system solutions, best-performing results from each track can motivate future solutions to the other. In addition, system metrics and results can inform hardware-independent algorithmic complexity metrics. Full size image Each NeuroBench track includes defined datasets, metric and measurement methodology, and modular evaluation components to enable flexible development. Promising methods identified from the algorithm track will inform system design by highlighting target algorithms for optimization and relevant system workloads for benchmarking. The system track in turn enables optimization and evaluation of performant implementations, providing feedback to refine algorithmic complexity modeling and analysis. The interplay between the tracks creates a virtuous cycle: algorithm innovations guide system implementation, while system-level insights accelerate further algorithmic progress. This approach allows NeuroBench to advance neuromorphic algorithm-system co-design. Both the algorithm and system track will be extended and co-developed as NeuroBench continues to expand. In the next few sections, we describe the algorithm track, including general complexity metric definitions, benchmark tasks, and common infrastructure tooling. We apply the framework to report baseline results for each algorithm benchmark, which outline unexplored research opportunities in optimizing algorithmic architectures and training of sparse, stateful models to achieve greater performance and resource efficiency. Then, we show baseline results established in the system track to assess neuromorphic performance across promising application workloads. By outlining both tracks, we provide a roadmap towards standardizing benchmark procedures in both hardware-independent and hardware dependent settings.

sentences.sentence: In recent years, the rapid growth of artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning (ML) has resulted in increasingly complex and large models in pursuit of higher accuracy and range of use cases [1].
viewpoints: The rapid growth of artificial intelligence and machine learning in recent years has led to models that are increasingly complex and large.

viewpoints: The growth rate of model computation in AI and ML exceeds the efficiency gains achieved by Moore and Dennard technology scaling.

sentences.sentence: This issue is compounded by the open challenges of adapting such methods for resource-constrained edge devices (tinyML) in order to enable pervasive and decentralized intelligence through the Internet of Things (IoT) [3].

viewpoints: There is an intensified urgency to explore new resource-efficient and scalable computing architectures.

sentences.sentence: Neuromorphic computing has emerged as a promising area in addressing these challenges, aiming to unlock key hallmarks of biological intelligence by porting primitives and computational strategies employed in the brain into engineered computing devices and algorithms [4], [5], [6].

6.1: Neuromorphic engineering encompasses a diverse range of approaches to information processing inspired by neurobiological systems.

6.21: The review article highlights the capabilities that each neuromorphic spiking emulator can deliver to neural modelers.
6.22: The article focuses on the discussion of large-scale emulators.
6.23: The article is a continuation of a previous review of various neural and synapse circuits.
6.24: The article explores applications where neuromorphic emulators have been used.
6.25: The article discusses some promising future applications of neuromorphic emulators.

7.1: Biological information-processing systems operate on principles completely different from those familiar to most engineers.
7.2: Biological solutions are many orders of magnitude more effective than digital methods for problems where the input data are ill-conditioned.
7.3: Biological solutions are many orders of magnitude more effective than digital methods for problems where the computation can be specified in a relative manner.
7.4: The advantage of biological information-processing systems is attributed to the use of elementary physical phenomena as computational primitives.
7.5: The advantage of biological information-processing systems is attributed to the representation of information by the relative values of analog signals rather than by the absolute values of digital signals.
7.6: Adaptive techniques are required in the approach of using biological information-processing systems to mitigate the effects of component differences.
7.7: Adaptation in biological information-processing systems leads naturally to systems that learn about their environment.
7.8: Large-scale adaptive analog systems are more robust to component degradation and failure than more conventional systems.
7.9: Large-scale adaptive analog systems use far less power than more conventional systems.
7.10: Adaptive analog technology can be expected to utilize the full potential of wafer-scale silicon fabrication due to its robustness and low power usage.

viewpoints: The initial definition of "neuromorphic" referred to approaches that aimed to emulate the biophysics of the brain.

11.1: Creating datasets for Neuromorphic Vision is challenging.

11.8: The method uses an actuated pan-tilt camera platform.
11.9: Moving the sensor rather than the scene or image is a more biologically realistic approach to sensing.
11.10: Moving the sensor rather than the scene or image eliminates timing artifacts introduced by monitor updates when simulating motion on a computer monitor.

11.12: MNIST and Caltech101 datasets have played important roles in the development of Computer Vision.

11.16: Converting datasets already popular in Computer Vision enables more direct comparison with frame-based approaches.

13.18: These results serve as the first reference for future performance comparisons of spiking neural networks.

viewpoints: Closed definitions can impose narrow assumptions.
Closed definitions risk unfairly excluding promising methods.

sentences.sentence: This challenge necessitates inclusive benchmarks that can be applied generally across the spectrum of potential approaches, allowing for flexible implementation while focusing on task capabilities and metrics of interest such as temporal processing and efficiency.
viewpoints: The challenge of defining benchmarks necessitates inclusive benchmarks.
Inclusive benchmarks should be applicable generally across potential approaches.
Inclusive benchmarks should allow for flexible implementation.
Inclusive benchmarks should focus on task capabilities and metrics such as temporal processing and efficiency.

sentences.sentence: Furthermore, the benchmarks should ideally allow for direct comparison of neuromorphic and conventional approaches.
viewpoints: Benchmarks should ideally allow for direct comparison of neuromorphic and conventional approaches.

sentences.sentence: Implementation diversity—A wide array of different frameworks targeting different goals, such as neuroscientific exploration [17] and automatic SNN training [18], are used in neuromorphic research.

18.1: The brain is an ideal source of inspiration for developing more efficient neural networks.
18.2: The inner workings of synapses and neurons provide a glimpse into the future potential of deep learning.
18.3: The article serves as a tutorial on applying research lessons from deep learning, gradient descent, backpropagation, and neuroscience to spiking neural networks.
18.4: The article offers a perspective on the application of research lessons to biologically plausible spiking neural networks.
18.5: The authors explore the interplay between encoding data as spikes and the learning process in neural networks.
18.6: The authors examine the challenges and solutions of applying gradient-based learning to spiking neural networks.
18.7: The authors investigate the link between temporal backpropagation and spike timing-dependent plasticity.
18.8: The authors discuss how deep learning might progress towards biologically plausible online learning.
18.9: Some ideas discussed in the article are well accepted and commonly used among the neuromorphic engineering community.
18.10: Some ideas in the article are presented or justified for the first time.
18.11: A series of companion interactive tutorials complementary to the article are made available using the Python package, snnTorch.

viewpoints: There is implementation diversity in neuromorphic research.
A wide array of different frameworks targets various goals in neuromorphic research.
Goals in neuromorphic research include neuroscientific exploration and automatic SNN training.

sentences.sentence: This diversity, which has been instrumental in exploring the landscape of bio-inspired techniques following different methodologies and abstraction levels, comes at the cost of portability and standardization, which in turn limits the ease of benchmark implementation.
viewpoints: Diversity in frameworks has been instrumental in exploring bio-inspired techniques.
Diversity follows different methodologies and abstraction levels.
Diversity in implementations comes at the cost of portability and standardization.
Limited portability and standardization limit the ease of benchmark implementation.

sentences.sentence: Benchmarks require common infrastructure that unites tooling to enable actionable implementation and comparison of new methods.
viewpoints: Benchmarks require a common infrastructure.
Common infrastructure should unite tooling for actionable implementation and comparison of new methods.

sentences.sentence: Rapid research evolution—Neuromorphic approaches are continually and rapidly evolving as part of an emerging field.
viewpoints: Neuromorphic approaches are continually evolving.
The evolution of neuromorphic approaches is part of an emerging field.

sentences.sentence: As the research community continues to make technological progress, so too should benchmark suites and methodology expand to foster inclusion and capture salient performance metrics.
viewpoints: Benchmark suites and methodology should expand alongside technological progress.
Expansion of benchmark suites should foster inclusion and capture salient performance metrics.

sentences.sentence: An iterative benchmark framework with structured versioning will facilitate productive foundational and evolving performance evaluation.
viewpoints: An iterative benchmark framework will facilitate productive foundational and evolving performance evaluation.
An iterative benchmark framework should have structured versioning.

sentences.sentence: To tackle these challenges, this article presents NeuroBench, a dual-track, multi-task benchmark framework.
viewpoints: This article presents NeuroBench as a dual-track, multi-task benchmark framework.
NeuroBench is intended to tackle the challenges in neuromorphic research.

sentences.sentence: NeuroBench addresses the existing neuromorphic benchmark challenges by advancing prior work in three distinct ways.
viewpoints: NeuroBench addresses existing challenges in neuromorphic benchmarks.
NeuroBench advances prior work in neuromorphic benchmarks in three distinct ways.

sentences.sentence: Firstly, the benchmark framework reduces assumptions regarding the specific solution being assessed, encouraging inclusive participation of neuromorphic and non-neuromorphic approaches by utilizing general, task-level benchmarking and hierarchical metric definitions which capture key performance indicators of interest.
viewpoints: The NeuroBench framework reduces assumptions about specific solutions being assessed.
Reduced assumptions encourage inclusive participation of both neuromorphic and non-neuromorphic approaches.
NeuroBench uses general, task-level benchmarking.
NeuroBench employs hierarchical metric definitions which capture key performance indicators.

sentences.sentence: Secondly, the NeuroBench benchmarks are associated with a common open-source benchmark harness tool which facilitates actionable benchmark implementation and offers structure for further expansion to neuromorphic algorithm frameworks and systems.
viewpoints: NeuroBench benchmarks are linked with a common open-source benchmark harness tool.
The benchmark harness tool facilitates actionable benchmark implementation.
The benchmark harness tool provides structure for further expansion to neuromorphic algorithm frameworks and systems.

sentences.sentence: Finally, NeuroBench establishes an iterative, community-driven initiative designed to evolve over time to ensure representation and relevance to neuromorphic research, analogous to the well-established MLPerf benchmark framework for machine learning [19], [20].
viewpoints: NeuroBench establishes an iterative, community-driven initiative.
The initiative is designed to evolve over time to ensure representation and relevance to neuromorphic research.
NeuroBench is analogous to the well-established MLPerf benchmark framework for machine learning.

sentences.sentence: As a whole, NeuroBench intends to align the neuromorphic research community on standard benchmarking, providing a dynamically evolving platform to ensure ongoing relevance and facilitate advancements through workshops, competitions, and a centralized leaderboard.
viewpoints: NeuroBench intends to align the neuromorphic research community on standard benchmarking.
NeuroBench provides a dynamically evolving platform to ensure ongoing relevance.
NeuroBench facilitates advancements through workshops, competitions, and a centralized leaderboard.

sentences.sentence: As Fig. 1 shows, the NeuroBench framework involves two tracks to enable agile algorithm and system development.
viewpoints: The NeuroBench framework involves two tracks.
The two tracks enable agile algorithm and system development.

sentences.sentence: As an emerging technology, neuromorphic hardware has not converged to a single platform which is commercially available, thus a large fraction of neuromorphic research explores algorithmic advancement on conventional systems which may not be optimal for performance.
viewpoints: Neuromorphic hardware has not converged to a single commercially available platform as an emerging technology.
A large fraction of neuromorphic research explores algorithmic advancement on conventional systems.
Conventional systems may not be optimal for performance in neuromorphic research.

sentences.sentence: Thus, NeuroBench consists of an algorithm track for hardware-independent evaluation and a system track for fully deployed solutions.
viewpoints: NeuroBench consists of an algorithm track for hardware-independent evaluation.
NeuroBench consists of a system track for fully deployed solutions.

sentences.sentence: The algorithm track defines four novel benchmarks for neuromorphic methods across diverse domains, namely few-shot continual learning, computer vision, motor cortical decoding, and chaotic forecasting, and utilizes complexity metrics to analyze solution costs.
viewpoints: The algorithm track defines four novel benchmarks for neuromorphic methods.
The domains for the benchmarks are few-shot continual learning, computer vision, motor cortical decoding, and chaotic forecasting.
The algorithm track uses complexity metrics to analyze solution costs.

sentences.sentence: Such hardware-independent benchmarking enables algorithmic exploration and prototyping, especially when simulating algorithm execution on non-neuromorphic platforms.
viewpoints: Hardware-independent benchmarking enables algorithmic exploration and prototyping.
It is particularly beneficial when simulating algorithm execution on non-neuromorphic platforms.

sentences.sentence: Meanwhile, the system track defines standard protocols to measure the real-world speed and efficiency of neuromorphic hardware on benchmarks ranging from standard machine learning tasks to promising fields for neuromorphic systems, such as optimization.
viewpoints: The system track defines standard protocols to measure the real-world speed and efficiency of neuromorphic hardware.
The benchmarks for the system track range from standard machine learning tasks to fields like optimization.

sentences.sentence: Up-to-date information on the latest benchmarks and official results can be found on the NeuroBench website (https://neurobench.ai/).
viewpoints: Up-to-date information on the latest benchmarks and official results can be found on the NeuroBench website.

sentences.sentence: Fig. 1: The two NeuroBench tracks: algorithms and systems.
viewpoints: The two NeuroBench tracks are algorithms and systems.

sentences.sentence: Grey boxes designate what is defined by the benchmark, and orange boxes indicate what is unique to each solution.
viewpoints: In Fig. 1, grey boxes designate what is defined by the benchmark.
In Fig. 1, orange boxes indicate what is unique to each solution.

sentences.sentence: Connecting arrows between the two tracks denote the co-innovation between the tracks and the cross-stack innovation enabled by this approach.
viewpoints: In Fig. 1, connecting arrows between the two tracks denote the co-innovation between the tracks.
The connecting arrows also represent the cross-stack innovation enabled by the NeuroBench approach.

sentences.sentence: Between algorithm and system solutions, best-performing results from each track can motivate future solutions to the other.
viewpoints: Best-performing results from each NeuroBench track can motivate future solutions for the other track.

sentences.sentence: In addition, system metrics and results can inform hardware-independent algorithmic complexity metrics.
viewpoints: System metrics and results can inform hardware-independent algorithmic complexity metrics.

sentences.sentence: Each NeuroBench track includes defined datasets, metric and measurement methodology, and modular evaluation components to enable flexible development.
viewpoints: Each NeuroBench track includes defined datasets.
Each NeuroBench track includes metric and measurement methodology.
Each NeuroBench track includes modular evaluation components for flexible development.

sentences.sentence: Promising methods identified from the algorithm track will inform system design by highlighting target algorithms for optimization and relevant system workloads for benchmarking.
viewpoints: Promising methods identified from the algorithm track will inform system design.
Promising methods will highlight target algorithms for optimization.
Promising methods will highlight relevant system workloads for benchmarking.

sentences.sentence: The system track in turn enables optimization and evaluation of performant implementations, providing feedback to refine algorithmic complexity modeling and analysis.
viewpoints: The system track enables optimization and evaluation of performant implementations.
The system track provides feedback to refine algorithmic complexity modeling and analysis.

sentences.sentence: The interplay between the tracks creates a virtuous cycle: algorithm innovations guide system implementation, while system-level insights accelerate further algorithmic progress.
viewpoints: The interplay between the tracks creates a virtuous cycle.
Algorithm innovations guide system implementation.
System-level insights accelerate further algorithmic progress.

sentences.sentence: This approach allows NeuroBench to advance neuromorphic algorithm-system co-design.
viewpoints: The NeuroBench approach allows for advancement in neuromorphic algorithm-system co-design.

sentences.sentence: Both the algorithm and system track will be extended and co-developed as NeuroBench continues to expand.
viewpoints: Both the algorithm and system tracks will be extended and co-developed as NeuroBench expands.

sentences.sentence: In the next few sections, we describe the algorithm track, including general complexity metric definitions, benchmark tasks, and common infrastructure tooling.
viewpoints: The next sections will describe the algorithm track.
The algorithm track description will include general complexity metric definitions, benchmark tasks, and common infrastructure tooling.

sentences.sentence: We apply the framework to report baseline results for each algorithm benchmark, which outline unexplored research opportunities in optimizing algorithmic architectures and training of sparse, stateful models to achieve greater performance and resource efficiency.
viewpoints: The NeuroBench framework is used to report baseline results for each algorithm benchmark.
Baseline results outline unexplored research opportunities in optimizing algorithmic architectures.
Baseline results outline training opportunities for sparse, stateful models to achieve greater performance and resource efficiency.

sentences.sentence: Then, we show baseline results established in the system track to assess neuromorphic performance across promising application workloads.
viewpoints: Baseline results in the system track will be shown to assess neuromorphic performance.
Baseline results will assess neuromorphic performance across promising application workloads.

sentences.sentence: By outlining both tracks, we provide a roadmap towards standardizing benchmark procedures in both hardware-independent and hardware dependent settings.
viewpoints: Outlining both tracks provides a roadmap towards standardizing benchmark procedures.
The standardization applies to both hardware-independent and hardware-dependent settings.
